articles.title: Bethlehem Christmas tree lights up for first time since start of Gaza war
articles.summary: For the past two years all public Christmas celebrations have been cancelled in Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank.
articles.content:
Bethlehem Christmas tree lights up for first time since start of Gaza war

13 hours ago Share Save Yolande Knell Middle East correspondent, Bethlehem Share Save

Watch: Bethlehem Christmas tree lights up for first time since Gaza war

For two years during the Gaza war, all public celebrations for Christmas were cancelled in Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank – where Christians believe Jesus was born. But after the recent ceasefire, the holy city decided that this year the festivities would return as symbolised by the lighting of its traditional, giant Christmas tree in front of the historic Nativity Church. "It's been a bad two years of silence; no Christmas, no jobs, no work," says Bethlehem Mayor Maher Canawati. "We're all living here from tourism and tourism was down to zero." The mayor accepts that the idea of resuming celebrations was not without controversy, as suffering continues in Gaza – including for those in its tiny Christian community, many of whom have relatives in Bethlehem.

"Some may say it's not appropriate and others say it's appropriate," Mr Canawati tells me. "But deep inside my heart, I felt that this was the right thing to do because Christmas should never be stopped or cancelled. This is the light of hope for us." Locals – both Christians and Muslims - pose for selfies in front of the tree hung with red and gold baubles in Manger Square. They are joined by a handful of foreign tourists. Brightly coloured lights now decorate the streets and there are signs advertising Christmas bazaars and children's parties.

Mayor Maher Canawati was keen to resume Christmas celebrations in Bethlehem

"We're very happy to have the tree, first thing, and to see foreigners in Bethlehem and to be able to celebrate Christmas in its true spirit," says local jewellery designer Nadya Hazboun. "This is where it all started, so this is where we can send the message to the world of what really Christmas should be about. And this year, if Christmas is peaceful, then I hope it will bring a nice message for the whole world." The neighbouring towns of Beit Jala and Beit Sahour are also planning to light Christmas trees in the coming days. Hotels – which have stood largely empty for the past two years – have an influx of bookings from Palestinian citizens of Israel as well as some foreign visitors.

Nadya Hazboun is very happy that the tree is back and tourists are returning to Bethlehem

One tourist from Russia, Angelica, is on her second pilgrimage to the Holy Land. "I think everyone needs to come at least once in their life," she tells me. "I hope a lot of people will soon come back because it's sad without many tourists. The only thing that's good is that you don't have long lines – you can come and see more things. When I came before you had to wait in line for a few hours minimum." For now, the souvenir stores dotted around Bethlehem have little business, and outside the cream-coloured walls of the Nativity Church, which date back to the Fourth Century, tour guides largely stand idle. Prior to the Gaza war, it was often crammed with people. One guide, Hamza, is worried that ongoing news coverage makes people feel the situation is still dangerous. He insists it is safe. "This is a tourist city; without tourism there is no life," Hamza laments. "We hope to have people coming back like before: from Europe, the Middle East, America, Latin America and everywhere. We start with the Christmas tree lighting, and we'll wait." In the past two years, unemployment has skyrocketed in Bethlehem. Since the deadly Hamas-led attacks on southern Israel in October 2023 which triggered the war, tens of thousands of Palestinian labourers from the West Bank have been blocked from entering Israel and its settlements for work. Meanwhile, public servants have received only partial salaries by the Palestinian Authority (PA) – which governs parts of the West Bank. The PA relies on tax revenues collected by Israel which it is withholding – to the tune of $1.76 billion, according to the UN's trade and development agency. Israel says it is holding the funds because the PA makes payments to Palestinian prisoners that incentivise attacks on Israelis. The authority – which has been under international pressure to make reforms – says it has recently changed its welfare system

Alaa Salameh, owner of family-run Afteem restaurant

articles.personality_title: Bethlehem lights up its Christmas tree again after two years of silence
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bethlehem, a city in the West Bank where Christians believe Jesus was born, had to cancel all public Christmas celebrations for two years because of the Gaza war and ongoing conflict.

**What happened** – After a recent ceasefire, Bethlehem lit up its giant Christmas tree in front of the Nativity Church for the first time since the war started. This event marked the return of public Christmas festivities, with lights, decorations, and plans for bazaars and children’s parties.

**Impact** – The lighting of the tree brought new hope and boosted community spirit in a city hit hard by war and unemployment. Both Christians and Muslims gathered to celebrate, and tourists started coming back after a long absence. For locals, this event symbolized a step toward normal life and helped support businesses that depend on visitors.

**What’s next step** – Neighboring towns Beit Jala and Beit Sahour plan to light their Christmas trees soon. Hotels are receiving more bookings, and locals hope tourism will continue to grow, helping the city recover economically and socially.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bethlehem’s Christmas tree lighting signals a hopeful return to tradition and community life after two difficult years of conflict and silence.
articles.personality_title_fr: Bethléem rallume son sapin de Noël après deux ans de silence
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Bethléem, une ville en Cisjordanie où les chrétiens croient que Jésus est né, a dû annuler toutes les célébrations publiques de Noël pendant deux ans à cause de la guerre à Gaza et du conflit en cours.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Après un récent cessez-le-feu, Bethléem a allumé son grand sapin de Noël devant l’église de la Nativité pour la première fois depuis le début de la guerre. Cet événement a marqué le retour des festivités publiques de Noël, avec des lumières, des décorations et des projets de marchés et de fêtes pour enfants.

**Impact** – L’allumage du sapin a apporté un nouvel espoir et redonné du courage à une communauté durement touchée par la guerre et le chômage. Chrétiens et musulmans se sont réunis pour célébrer, et les touristes ont commencé à revenir après une longue absence. Pour les habitants, cet événement symbolise un pas vers une vie normale et soutient les commerces qui dépendent des visiteurs.

**Prochaine étape** – Les villes voisines Beit Jala et Beit Sahour prévoient d’allumer leurs sapins de Noël bientôt. Les hôtels reçoivent plus de réservations, et les habitants espèrent que le tourisme continuera à se développer, aidant la ville à se remettre économiquement et socialement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’allumage du sapin de Noël à Bethléem marque un retour plein d’espoir aux traditions et à la vie communautaire après deux années difficiles de conflit et de silence.
articles.personality_title_es: Belén enciende su árbol de Navidad tras dos años de silencio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Belén, una ciudad en Cisjordania donde los cristianos creen que nació Jesús, tuvo que cancelar todas las celebraciones públicas de Navidad durante dos años debido a la guerra en Gaza y el conflicto en curso.

**Qué pasó** – Tras un reciente alto el fuego, Belén encendió su gran árbol de Navidad frente a la Iglesia de la Natividad por primera vez desde que comenzó la guerra. Este evento marcó el regreso de las festividades públicas de Navidad, con luces, decoraciones y planes para bazares y fiestas infantiles.

**Impacto** – Encender el árbol trajo nueva esperanza y levantó el ánimo de la comunidad, que sufrió mucho por la guerra y el desempleo. Cristianos y musulmanes se reunieron para celebrar, y los turistas comenzaron a regresar después de una larga ausencia. Para los locales, este evento simboliza un paso hacia la vida normal y apoya a los negocios que dependen de los visitantes.

**Próximo paso** – Las ciudades vecinas Beit Jala y Beit Sahour planean encender sus árboles de Navidad pronto. Los hoteles están recibiendo más reservas y los habitantes esperan que el turismo siga creciendo, ayudando a la ciudad a recuperarse económica y socialmente.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La iluminación del árbol de Navidad en Belén señala un regreso esperanzador a la tradición y a la vida comunitaria tras dos años difíciles de conflicto y silencio.

articles.title: From ruins to rebuilding: Three Jamaican mothers face the future after hurricane
articles.summary: Three women in Jamaica whose lives were upended by the destructive force of a hurricane which battered the Caribbean island are looking to rebuild their future
articles.content:
Three women in Jamaica whose lives were upended by the destructive force of a hurricane which battered the Caribbean island are looking to rebuild their future.

Right before Hurricane Melissa swept across Jamaica in late October 2025, Rose* took her two children to a friend’s sturdy concrete home to keep them safe. When they returned the next morning, everything had vanished.

“The house was gone,” she said. “I didn’t even see the roof, just a piece of lumber.”

© IOM/Nicholas Renford A school serves a temporary shelter for people whose lives were upended by Hurricane Melissa.

Entire neighbourhoods were reduced to splinters by the hurricane which left 36 per cent of houses in the western part of the country either damaged or destroyed.

Schools became shelters overnight, turning classrooms into temporary homes. Roads disappeared under water, power outages spread, and thousands were cut off for days.

Nearly half a million people were left in precarious living conditions, facing profound uncertainty.

Among them are Rose, Sharon, and Sonia – three mothers whose lives changed overnight.

‘I have a key but no house’

For nine years, Rose lived in her small wooden home, a donated structure that had become her family’s refuge.

Now, only the foundation remains. “I have a key to the house but no house,” she said. The air reeked of mud and decay. Nothing could be saved.

© IOM/Nicholas Renford Sonia sits on a bed at a shelter for people who lost their homes due to Hurricane Melissa.

Before the storm, Rose worked as a cruise dispatcher in Negril, and her son as a hotel photographer. Both lost their jobs when the tourism industry shut down.

A few classrooms away, Sharon* faces a similar struggle. She arrived at the shelter with her two small children the same day her home, and her father’s collapsed.

Before the storm, she worked as a gas station supervisor, now her workplace is closed indefinitely. Her children sleep on desks in the sweltering heat.

Between the rows of desks and makeshift beds, families share what little they have: a meal, a blanket, a few words of comfort. Amid loss, small acts of kindness create fragile connections.

Living in limbo

More than 1,100 people remain in 88 shelters in Jamaica, and over 120,000 households need urgent repairs after Melissa’s destruction.

Among them is Sonia*, who fled her coastal home carrying her grandson with a heart condition.

“I can’t swim, so I grabbed him and ran,” she recalled.

Since the start of the emergency, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) teams have supported the Government of Jamaica and the wider UN response, delivering tarpaulins, shelter repair materials, hygiene kits, generators, and other essentials to families whose homes were damaged or destroyed.

For women like Rose, Sharon, and Sonia, each day is a test of endurance and solidarity. Their homes are gone, but the support of their communities helps them move forward.

Their lives, once far apart, are now linked by loss, uncertainty, and the slow process of rebuilding.

*Names changed to protect identities

articles.personality_title: Jamaican mothers rebuild their lives after Hurricane Melissa
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In late October 2025, Hurricane Melissa struck Jamaica, causing severe damage. About 36% of homes in the western part of the island were damaged or destroyed, leaving nearly half a million people in difficult living conditions.

**What happened** – Three mothers, Rose, Sharon, and Sonia, lost their homes and livelihoods because of the hurricane. They and many others found shelter in schools turned into temporary homes. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the Jamaican government provided help with supplies like tarps, hygiene kits, and repair materials.

**Impact** – The hurricane caused major disruption by destroying homes and closing workplaces, but the response effort has helped many families survive and begin to recover. The support given to these women shows how communities and aid organizations can work together to face extreme challenges.

**What's next step** – Repairing over 120,000 homes and helping families move out of shelters will take time. Continued aid and rebuilding projects will focus on restoring homes and jobs so people like Rose, Sharon, and Sonia can rebuild stable lives.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After Hurricane Melissa destroyed homes and jobs in Jamaica, strong community support and aid efforts are helping families rebuild their lives step by step.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des mères jamaïcaines reconstruisent leur vie après l'ouragan Melissa
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Fin octobre 2025, l'ouragan Melissa a frappé la Jamaïque, causant de lourds dégâts. Environ 36 % des maisons dans l'ouest de l'île ont été endommagées ou détruites, laissant près d'un demi-million de personnes dans des conditions difficiles.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Trois mères, Rose, Sharon et Sonia, ont perdu leur maison et leur travail à cause de l'ouragan. Elles, ainsi que beaucoup d'autres, ont trouvé refuge dans des écoles transformées en abris temporaires. L'Organisation internationale pour les migrations (OIM) et le gouvernement jamaïcain ont fourni des aides comme des bâches, des trousses d'hygiène et des matériaux de réparation.

**Impact** – L'ouragan a causé de grands bouleversements en détruisant des maisons et en fermant des emplois, mais les efforts d'aide ont permis à de nombreuses familles de survivre et de commencer à se reconstruire. Le soutien apporté à ces femmes montre comment les communautés et les organisations d'aide peuvent s'unir face à des défis extrêmes.

**Prochaine étape** – Réparer plus de 120 000 maisons et aider les familles à quitter les abris prendra du temps. Les projets de reconstruction continueront à se concentrer sur le rétablissement des logements et des emplois pour que des personnes comme Rose, Sharon et Sonia puissent reconstruire une vie stable.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Après la destruction causée par l'ouragan Melissa en Jamaïque, le soutien communautaire et les efforts d'aide permettent aux familles de reconstruire leur vie pas à pas.
articles.personality_title_es: Madres jamaicanas reconstruyen sus vidas tras el huracán Melissa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – A finales de octubre de 2025, el huracán Melissa golpeó Jamaica, causando graves daños. Cerca del 36 % de las casas en la parte occidental de la isla fueron dañadas o destruidas, dejando a casi medio millón de personas en condiciones difíciles.

**Qué pasó** – Tres madres, Rose, Sharon y Sonia, perdieron sus hogares y trabajos debido al huracán. Ellas, junto con muchas otras personas, encontraron refugio en escuelas que se convirtieron en hogares temporales. La Organización Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM) y el gobierno jamaicano proporcionaron ayuda con lonas, kits de higiene y materiales para reparaciones.

**Impacto** – El huracán causó grandes problemas al destruir casas y cerrar lugares de trabajo, pero la respuesta de ayuda ha permitido que muchas familias sobrevivan y comiencen a recuperarse. El apoyo a estas mujeres muestra cómo las comunidades y las organizaciones de ayuda pueden unirse para enfrentar grandes desafíos.

**Próximo paso** – Reparar más de 120,000 hogares y ayudar a las familias a salir de los refugios llevará tiempo. Los proyectos de reconstrucción seguirán enfocándose en restaurar hogares y empleos para que personas como Rose, Sharon y Sonia puedan construir una vida estable.

**Una frase clave** – Tras la destrucción del huracán Melissa en Jamaica, el apoyo comunitario y los esfuerzos de ayuda están ayudando a las familias a reconstruir sus vidas paso a paso.
